bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, July 7, 1900

div1.p: Reed describes his laboratory, the hot weather and mosquitoes. He reviews work to be done at Keewaydin.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, July 7, 1900
div1.opener:
No. 13
Saturday 6 am
Regards to Cora
& Carrie.
WAR DEPARTMENT,
SURGEON GENERAL'S OFFICE,
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM AND LIBRARY,
WASHINGTON.
Camp Columbia,
Quemados,
Cuba,
July 7, 1900
My precious wifie:
div1.p:
Last Monday
morning the Postman told us
that beginning with the 1st of
July, we would only receive
3 mails per week instead
of 5 as heretofore- These
three mails will arrive Mondays,
Wednesday & Saturday and leave
on the same days- I wrote to
my darling wifie early on Wed=
nesday morning, July 4th, and mailed
it in time for the Postman-
The same day I got a sweet letter
from my sweet Farmer-lady.
Thursday we were so busily at
work all day trying to arrange
our laboratory & other things
for future work, that I didn't
write and yesterday we rode into
Havana, and when I got back
I felt so tired after dinner, that
I went to bed early- These
are therefore the only two days
since I left, that I haven't written
to my precious children- My letters
wouldn't have gone until, this
morning, Saturday- I will hereafter
write early on Monday, Wednesday
& Saturday- I don't know on what
days to tell you, lovie, dear, to
write so that your letters will reach
me soonest, but if you wrote
every day or have precious plump
piano-player fill in the days
I should be very happy with
the arrangement. The Boats leave
Tampa on Monday, Thursday and
Saturday- Don't bother your darling
head about it, as I will get them
on the next Boat, if your letters
happen to miss one- I am so glad
that my letter written on the boat
didn't go astray- I wanted you &
precious joy to know how much I had
really enjoyed the journey- As for
Heat & mosquitoes, sweet heart,
the latter are here in some numbers
but not enough to bother me, &
the former is much less trying
than in Washington. For two days
it has been warmer, but not warm
enough to bother me at all- I have
a good Chinaman for a laundryman
& can change as often as I please-
my clothes are, also, thinner than I have
ever worn- I got yesterday in Havana
a large Cork Helmet, with which I
propose to decorate my upper story
when I go in the Sun. I was amused
at Mrs. Roach's desire to have half of
the rails- I had already spoken to
Dr Roach about it & had told Mr Moore
where to put them- Of course, she won't
have but half- I wan't the other half
myself!- Boo! Boo! If there are still
stone left that can be used, let
Mr Moore continue on down the road
till he strikes the fence Mr Flohr has
built- Ask Johnnie Moore what he
thinks of it: Now is as good a time as
any for building the fence: or let him
clear the rocks from my precious wifie's
park & build that little piece of fence,
Saving one half the rails! I could
just see Mrs. Farmer-lady when
that hard western breeze was
blowing! Why didn't you get into
the cellar? Certainly nothing could
be more disagreeable than those
everlasting western blows- They
are apt to occur in July. I think-
you musn't really get discouraged
about those astors & c- Put some
more bone meal around them
& make them grow! Take them
by the tops & pull them up until
they are real tall! Am so glad
that you will soon have veg-
etables- I know that my darling
wifie and my sweet baby will
enjoy them so much- Of course,
you musn't expect to have as
good a garden the first year
after upturning the soil, but
it will improve each year.
I don't understand the first
corn & still think that you
must be mistaken in saying
that it won't amount to anything.
Have Jacob work it & the other
corn every week & I am cer-
tain that it will do well-
But don't bother yourself &
work too hard over the
sann, my precious heart --
you might make yourself
sick- Why don't my precious
love daughter write to her father
more frequently? She musn't
play with that pup & the
piano all the time! Are
Pud & Miss Beals large enough
to eat? They ought to be good
on toast a few weeks from
now- When is Lucy coming
up? I suppose that Fat auntie
has, at last, arrived- Give
her much love for me and
also to the girls- How is she
pleased with her new well?
Well, I must stop- The morn-
ing is cool and the sea beautiful.
Take care of your darling selves,
Love & kisses for my precious
sweet children- Darboy will
be out tomorrow -- write
often- Regards to Johnnie Moore & Jacob
